block.p: ''Too Cool on Global Warming'' (editorial, Feb. 8) contends that the Bush Administration is overcautious in developing a sound environmental policy. You suggest steps the President should take to reduce the threat of global warming and to protect the ozone layer.
One of those steps is to ban chemicals suspected of depleting the ozone layer. While this might be good in theory, it could create more immediate problems in practice.

For example, one chemical suspected of depleting the ozone layer is halon, used exclusively to fight fires. Halon is used in areas that house sophisticated computers and electronic equipment. Telecommunication companies, banks and the Government use halon because it is noncorrosive, nonconductive and nontoxic. When released, halon can quickly penetrate an electronic component and extinguish a fire within seconds. Because of halon's special properties, equipment untouched by fire will not be harmed.

One chemical thought to contribute to the problems of global warming is carbon dioxide. Carbon dioxide also plays an important role in fire protection. It protects sensitive equipment, including newspaper printing equipment, against the devastation of fire.

Three-fourths of all businesses that suffer a major fire are out of business in three years, fire statistics show. The Fire Suppression Systems Association works closely with business in specification, design and installation of special hazard fire-suppression systems, such as halon, carbon dioxide, dry chemicals and foam. Automatic systems are used in only the most critical applications.

There is no substitute for halon. While halon manufacturers work to find an environmentally acceptable alternative, the Government must protect those substances that protect society from fire. The President's cautious approach reflects the problems associated with simplistic chemical bans.
